The first time I was contacted by Manchester
Art Gallery, I received a really exciting

9.text:
email from Rebecca Milner who is a curator
there. She told me that she had this exhibition

15.text:
they were doing called 'Artists in the Frame',
which was also a collaboration with the National

21.text:
It's quite an unusual setting for a comic
book artist to be in – in a fine art gallery.

27.text:
I was very nervous at first and was thinking,
'what can I contribute to this?’ and then

31.text:
I reminded myself that I was there to do what
I do, which is to tell stories with pictures;

36.text:
I was a storyteller and I really wanted to
find a story inside the Van Dyck that was

42.text: my story and which I had the right to tell.

46.text:
The Van Dyck has this most incredibly elaborate
frame and there are stories around the edges

51.text:
of the frame: the symbolism of the dolphins,
of Charles I and the sunflower. I looked at

60.text:
Rubens and Van Dyck’s work as well as a
lot of examples of decorative ornate frames,

67.text:
and I really started to think about how I
wanted to incorporate that into my work.

72.text:
At first, I really struggled with this idea
of doing a self-portrait; I felt really uncomfortable

78.text:
about exposing a version of myself. I started
to think about it and thought wouldn't it

84.text:
be fantastic to look at the many different
versions of myself and have this kind of frame

90.text:
which depicted a battle between all the different
versions of myself fighting to be shown in

96.text:
the frame, and that inside the frame would
be blank?

100.text:
I wanted to depict not only a battle between
all my many selves fighting for representation

106.text:
in the frame, but also I wanted to look at
the process by which artists create art and

112.text:
which selves come to the foreground as this
process continues.

116.text:
So it starts off with that excitement, that
anxiety. I had these little red selves biting

123.text:
and nipping at the bottom of the frame. And
then from that bursts this kind of energetic

128.text:
self – she kind of zooms out of the frame
– she’s like this blue light energetic

133.text:
self, but then she becomes manic and twisted
up in her ideas and her thoughts and at that

139.text:
point the performative self strangles her
and kills hers.

144.text:
Then she gets her neck bitten by this destructive
self, and that self is the one you get when

151.text:
you're lying in bed at night and the voices
are going round and round in your head telling

155.text:
you ‘why do you bother and what are you
doing and is it worth it anyway?’

161.text:
What you have afterwards is that the destructive
self vomits out this vulnerable depressive

166.text: self who doesn't have any skin.

167.text:
But all the while through the story, we've
had this tiny little playful self who’s

172.text:
been skipping around and swinging and playing,
and she’s kind of like the child self who

179.text:
just enjoys making things. And eventually
she curls up and falls asleep in the meditative

186.text:
self. And she gives birth to the energetic
self who goes diving right back into the anxious

192.text: self. And so the circle continues.

197.text:
It was interesting doing this piece, because
it was the first time I've done such a large-scale

202.text:
paper cut-out and the first time I've ever
done a self-portrait. It did fit in with previous

207.text:
themes which I've explored and there’s a
very strong link between my graphic novel

212.text: ‘Death of the Artist’ and this piece.

215.text:
But what this ‘Selves Portrait’ also did
was it took my work in a different direction,

220.text:
it really forced me to – in a much more
honest way – look at my own work and also

227.text:
to kind of understand how you can create one
single piece to tell a narrative.

231.text:
You’ve got so much more space when you write
in a graphic novel, you have so many more

236.text:
pages to explore your story and with this
work it had to be done very concisely in one

245.text:
Once you’ve finished your piece and it's
off your table, the relationship isn’t between

250.text:
the artist and the audience, it’s between
the work and the audience, and it’s their

254.text: work to bounce their own ideas off.

257.text:
We had some events and workshops which we
did at Manchester. We also had a lot of people

262.text:
taking selfies which was great. I mean that's
what every artist wants. I want my work to

267.text:
be interactive, I want people to be able to
bring their own stories to it and it takes
